abstract.text: Send notifications to the user’s device with a JSON payload.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Remote notifications convey important information to the user in the form of a JSON payload. The payload specifies the types of user interactions (alert, sound, or badge) that you want performed, and includes any custom data your app needs to respond to the notification.

A basic remote notification payload includes Apple-defined keys and their custom values. You may also add custom keys and values specific to your notifications. Apple Push Notification service (APNs) refuses a notification if the total size of its payload exceeds the following limits:
For Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) notifications, the maximum payload size is 5 KB (5120 bytes).
For all other remote notifications, the maximum payload size is 4 KB (4096 bytes).
Specify the payload for a remote notification using a JSON dictionary. Inside this dictionary, include an

key whose value is a dictionary containing one or more additional Apple-defined keys, listed in Table 1. You can include keys instructing the system to display an alert, play a sound, or badge your app’s icon. You can also instruct the system to handle the notification silently in the background. For more information, see

In addition to the Apple-defined keys, you may add custom keys to your payload to deliver small amounts of data to your app, notification service app extension, or notification content app extension. Your custom keys must have values with primitive types, such as dictionary, array, string, number, or Boolean. Custom keys are available in the
dictionary of the
object delivered to your app.

Typically, you use custom keys to help your code process the notification. For example, you might include an identifier string that your code can use to look up app-specific data. Add app-specific keys as peers of the
dictionary.
Listing 1 shows a notification payload that displays an alert message inviting the user to play a game. If the
key identifies a previously registered
object, the system adds action buttons to the alert. For example, the category here includes a play action to start the game immediately. The custom
key contains an identifier that the app can use to retrieve the game invitation.
Listing 1. A remote notification payload for showing an alert
Listing 2 shows a notification payload that badges the app’s icon and plays a sound. The specified sound file must be on the user’s device already, either in the app’s bundle or in the
folder of the app’s container. The
key contains app-specific information for identifying the message that caused the notification.
Listing 2. A remote notification payload for playing a sound
For more information about creating sounds for your notifications, see

Don’t include customer information or any sensitive data, like a credit card number, in a notification’s payload. If you must include customer information or sensitive data, encrypt it before adding it to the payload. You can use a notification service app extension to decrypt the data on the user’s device. For more information, see
There are two ways to localize the content of remote notifications:
Include localized strings directly in the payload.
Add localized message strings in your app bundle, and let the system choose which strings to display.

Placing localized strings directly into the payload gives you more flexibility, but requires you to track the user’s preferred language on your provider server. Because your provider server supplies the strings, it must know which language to use. On the user’s device, you can retrieve the user’s preferred languages by examining the
property of
. Your app can then forward that information to your server.
If the text of your notification messages is predetermined, you can store your message strings in the
file of your app bundle and use the
, and

payload keys to specify which strings you want to display. Your localized strings may contain placeholders so that you can insert content dynamically into the final string. Listing 3 shows an example of a payload with a message derived from an app-provided string. The
key contains an array of replacement variables to substitute into the string.
Listing 3. A remote notification payload with localized content
For more information about the keys you use for localized content, see Table 2.
Table 1 lists the keys that you may include in the
dictionary. To interact with the user, include the
, or
keys. Don’t add your own custom keys to the
dictionary; APNs ignores custom keys. Instead, add your custom keys as peers of the
dictionary, as shown in Listing 1.
Table 1. Keys to include in the
dictionary
Key
Value type
Description
Dictionary (or String)
The information for displaying an alert. A dictionary is recommended. If you specify a string, the alert displays your string as the body text. For a list of dictionary keys, see Table 2.
Number
The number to display in a badge on your app’s icon. Specify
to remove the current badge, if any.
String
The name of a sound file in your app’s main bundle or in the
folder of your app’s container directory. Specify the string
to play the system sound. Use this key for regular notifications. For critical alerts, use the
dictionary instead. For information about how to prepare sounds, see
Dictionary
A dictionary that contains sound information for critical alerts. For regular notifications, use the
string instead.
String
An app-specific identifier for grouping related notifications. This value corresponds to the
property in the
object.
String
The notification’s type. This string must correspond to the
of one of the
objects you register at launch time. See
Number
The background notification flag. To perform a silent background update, specify the value

keys in your payload. See
Number
The notification service app extension flag. If the value is
, the system passes the notification to your notification service app extension before delivery. Use your extension to modify the notification’s content. See
String

object created from the push payload. Access the value using the

property.

If your remote notification updates a Live Activity, you can set any Double value; for example,
, or
String
The criteria the system evaluates to determine if it displays the notification in the current Focus. For more information, see
Number

Dictionary

implementation. For more information, see

inlineContent.code: Updating and ending your Live Activity with ActivityKit push notifications

inlineContent.text: Number
The UNIX timestamp that marks the time when you send the remote notification that updates or ends a Live Activity. For more information, see

inlineContent.code: Updating and ending your Live Activity with ActivityKit push notifications

inlineContent.text: String
The string that describes whether you start, update, or end an ongoing Live Activity with the remote push notification. To start the Live Activity, use
. To update the Live Activity, use
. To end the Live Activity, use
. For more information, see

inlineContent.code: Updating and ending your Live Activity with ActivityKit push notifications

inlineContent.text: Number
The UNIX timestamp that represents the date at which the system ends a Live Activity and removes it from the Dynamic Island and the Lock Screen. For more information, see

inlineContent.code: Updating and ending your Live Activity with ActivityKit push notifications

inlineContent.text: String

A string you use when you start a Live Activity with a remote push notification. It must match the name of the structure that describes the dynamic data that appears in a Live Activity. For more information, see

inlineContent.code: Updating and ending your Live Activity with ActivityKit push notifications

inlineContent.text: Dictionary
The dictionary that contains data you pass to a Live Activity that you start with a remote push notification. For more information, see

inlineContent.code: Updating and ending your Live Activity with ActivityKit push notifications

inlineContent.text: Table 2 lists the keys that you may include in the
dictionary. Use these strings to specify the title and message to include in the alert banner.
Table 2. Keys to include in the
dictionary
Key
Value type
Description
String
The title of the notification. Apple Watch displays this string in the short look notification interface. Specify a string that’s quickly understood by the user.
String
Additional information that explains the purpose of the notification.
String
The content of the alert message.
String
The name of the launch image file to display. If the user chooses to launch your app, the contents of the specified image or storyboard file are displayed instead of your app’s normal launch image.
String
The key for a localized title string. Specify this key instead of the
key to retrieve the title from your app’s
files. The value must contain the name of a key in your strings file.
Array of strings
An array of strings containing replacement values for variables in your title string. Each
character in the string specified by the
is replaced by a value from this array. The first item in the array replaces the first instance of the
character in the string, the second item replaces the second instance, and so on.
String
The key for a localized subtitle string. Use this key, instead of the
key, to retrieve the subtitle from your app’s
file. The value must contain the name of a key in your strings file.
Array of strings
An array of strings containing replacement values for variables in your title string. Each
character in the string specified by
is replaced by a value from this array. The first item in the array replaces the first instance of the
character in the string, the second item replaces the second instance, and so on.
String
The key for a localized message string. Use this key, instead of the
key, to retrieve the message text from your app’s
file. The value must contain the name of a key in your strings file.
Array of strings
An array of strings containing replacement values for variables in your message text. Each
character in the string specified by
is replaced by a value from this array. The first item in the array replaces the first instance of the
character in the string, the second item replaces the second instance, and so on.
Table 3 lists the keys that you may include in the
dictionary. Use these keys to configure the sound for a critical alert.
Table 3. Keys to include in the
dictionary
Key
Value type
Description
Number
The critical alert flag. Set to
to enable the critical alert.
String
The name of a sound file in your app’s main bundle or in the
folder of your app’s container directory. Specify the string
to play the system sound. For information about how to prepare sounds, see
Number
The volume for the critical alert’s sound. Set this to a value between
(silent) and
(full volume).

abstract.text: The protocol you implement to describe the content of a Live Activity.
Display your app’s data in the Dynamic Island and on the Lock Screen and offer quick interactions.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Displaying live data with Live Activities

abstract.text: An interface for providing an app intent that you use to adapt your app’s behavior when Focus changes.
Customize the appearance of your iOS app’s notification alerts with a notification content app extension.
An object representing information about linguistic, cultural, and technological conventions that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An ordered list of the user's preferred languages.
Push user-facing notifications to the user’s device from a server, or generate them locally from your app.
The identifier that groups related notifications.
A type of notification your app supports and the custom actions that the system displays.
The unique string assigned to the category.
The uneditable content of a notification.
The score the system uses to determine if the notification is the summary’s featured notification.
The value your app uses to determine which scene to display to handle the notification.
The custom data to associate with the notification.
Constants that indicate the importance and delivery timing of a notification.
The sound played upon delivery of a notification.
Differentiate your notifications and add action buttons to the notification interface.
Secure your communications with APNs to send API requests.

abstract.text: Communicate with Apple Push Notification service (APNs) and receive a unique device token that identifies your app.
Generate notifications and push them to user devices.
